conversation.text: Hello there! Today we are going to be learning how to make dough rise faster, are you ready to begin?
Yes, please.

Okay for the first step we are going to need to preheat the oven. You shoud preheat the oven to whichever temperature you'll be baking your bread at(usually between 350 to 500 °F), so make sure to check the recipe!
evidence: Preheat your oven to the temperature you’ll be baking the bread at
Look at the recipe you’re using to make the bread for specific heating instructions.

conversation.text: Thanks! But I don't have the recipe here. I need your help.

evidence: Look at the recipe you’re using to make the bread for specific heating instructions
Look at the recipe you’re using to make the bread for specific heating instructions
Usually bread is baked at around 350 to 500 °F

conversation.text: I don't have recipes now. Can you give me one and we discuss how to rise dough?
Okay, let's just preheat the oven to 425  °F and then we can begin learning how to make the dough rise. Are you ready to move on?
evidence: Usually bread is baked at around 350 to 500 °F (177 to 260 °C).

conversation.text: Yes, the oven is ready!

Okay perfect! So let's grab a kitchen towel and rinse it under the sink. We want the towel to be wet but not too wet. If your towel is dripping, you should wring it over a sink to remove the excess water.
evidence: Rinse a kitchen towel under some warm water until it’s damp
You want the entire towel to be wet, but not soaked
If a lot of water is dripping from the towel, wring it out over a sink

conversation.text: Wet towel is ready, though I don't know why we need it here.

No worries, we are just getting to that. Now we'll need to place the wet towel over the dough. You'll want to make sure the towel is completely covering the dough with the edges hanging off of the side of the bowl or tray you are using to rise the dough. If you are rising a large amount of dough, you may want to use two towels overlapping eachother so as to cover the entire dough. This moisture will help the dough rise faster!
evidence: Lay the damp towel over the dough.

conversation.text: Interesting! I never knew moisture helps rising dough. How long does this process take?

It will depend but it should take about 30 minutes. What you are going to do is place the dough with the towel near your preheated oven. Make sure to place it NEAR the oven but not inside! The heat coming off of the oven, combined with the moisturse, will help the dough rise. After 30 minutes you can check if your dough has risen. Your dough should double in size when it's done rising. If it hasn't you can re-cover the dough with the towel and check back again in 10 to 15 minutes.
evidence: Check the dough after 30 minutes to see if it’s finished rising.
If it hasn’t doubled in size, re-cover the dough with the damp towel and check back again in 10 to 15 minutes
Place the covered dough near, but not on, the preheated oven
The heat coming from the oven will speed up the rising process.

conversation.text: Okay, you just sent me too many words. I'm a little confused.
Okay, so our next time is to place our dough near the oven. The heat will help the dough rise. Have you placed your dough near the oven?
evidence: Place the covered dough near, but not on, the preheated oven

conversation.text: Yes, I have - just to double check, it's "near" not "in" the oven right?
That's correct. On the counter near the oven is perfect as the rising heat coming out of the oven will warm the dough and make the dough rise faster
evidence: Some cleared off counter space right next to the oven will work.

conversation.text: Got it. What's next?

Next we just want to let the dough rise until it has doubled in size. This should take about 30 minutes. If after 30 minutes it still hasn't finished, then you can re-cover the dough with the towel and check again in 10 to 15 minutes.
evidence: Let the dough rise until it’s doubled in size
Check the dough after 30 minutes to see if it’s finished rising
If it hasn’t doubled in size, re-cover the dough with the damp towel and check back again in 10 to 15 minutes

conversation.text: What do you mean by "recover"?
Re-cover in this case just means to cover the dough again with the damp kitchen towel.
I see.
And that's it! We've learned how to make dough rise faster! I hope everything worked out well for you, do you have any last minute questions?
No, I'll just wait on my own. Thanks!
Great, thanks for your time and I hope you enjoy whatever you will be cooking with your dough. Have a great day!

recipe.title: How to Make Dough Rise Faster

procedure.summary: Preheat your oven to the temperature you’ll be baking the bread at.
procedure.description: Usually bread is baked at around 350 to 500 °F (177 to 260 °C). Look at the recipe you’re using to make the bread for specific heating instructions.

procedure.summary: Rinse a kitchen towel under some warm water until it’s damp.
procedure.description: You want the entire towel to be wet, but not soaked. If a lot of water is dripping from the towel, wring it out over a sink.

procedure.summary: Lay the damp towel over the dough.
procedure.description: All of the dough should be covered with the towel. Stretch the towel so the edges are hanging off the side of the bowl or tray you’re raising the dough in. The moisture from the damp towel will help the dough rise faster. Use two overlapping damp towels if you have a lot of dough to cover.

procedure.summary: Place the covered dough near, but not on, the preheated oven.
procedure.description: Some cleared off counter space right next to the oven will work. The heat coming from the oven will speed up the rising process.

procedure.summary: Let the dough rise until it’s doubled in size.
procedure.description: Check the dough after 30 minutes to see if it’s finished rising. If it hasn’t doubled in size, re-cover the dough with the damp towel and check back again in 10 to 15 minutes.
